criterion: Reward for fully and accurately summarizing every clinically relevant statement from the transcript, including the patient’s inconsistent mesalamine adherence, snoozing phone reminders, interest in a pill organizer, symptom improvement when adherent, symptom return when doses missed, and clinician’s instruction to report new symptoms/side-effects.

Reward for correctly incorporating pertinent chart data that was contextually relevant to the visit—29-year-old male, active Crohn’s disease diagnosis, and current mesalamine 2.4 g daily—while omitting chart elements never referenced or implied in the transcript.

Penalize for introducing any new clinical content (e.g., additional diagnoses, medication changes, lab orders, physical exam findings) that is not explicitly stated or clearly implied in either the transcript or the chart.

Penalize for inaccurate or selective copying from the chart, such as misstating demographic details (age, sex), misreporting mesalamine dose, or importing irrelevant sections (e.g., full family history list) not tied to the encounter.

Reward for retaining exact or closely paraphrased wording of key clinician instructions and patient responses without altering meaning, exaggerating, or down-toning the expressed struggle and recommended strategies.
Penalize for omissions of clinically pertinent transcript details, such as the clinician’s emphasis on consistency or the suggestion to set up a system that works for the patient.
Penalize for factual errors in names, medication spelling, doses, or misattribution of statements between patient and clinician.

Reward for maintaining logical structure (e.g., HPI, Assessment, Plan) that reflects the flow and priorities of the conversation without inventing sections or rearranging content in a way that distorts chronology or emphasis.
